What is the difference between 'undefined' and 'null' in TypeScript?
options: They are interchangeable and can be used interchangeably
'undefined' means a variable has been declared but not assigned a value, while 'null' is an assignment value representing no value or no object
'null' means a variable has been declared but not assigned a value, while 'undefined' is an assignment value representing no value or no object
There is no difference, they both represent the absence of a value
questions.answer: 'undefined' means a variable has been declared but not assigned a value, while 'null' is an assignment value representing no value or no object

questions.question: What is a 'type assertion' in TypeScript?
options: It allows you to specify the type of a value when TypeScript cannot determine the type on its own
It allows you to change the type of a value at runtime
It allows you to assert that a variable is of a certain type, even if TypeScript cannot determine the type on its own
It allows you to assert that a variable is not of a certain type
questions.answer: It allows you to assert that a variable is of a certain type, even if TypeScript cannot determine the type on its own
